title: "6-Frequency Tests"

author: "Felipe Melo"

format:
  revealjs:
    theme: [default, custom.scss]
    incremental: false
    chalkboard: true
    logo: img/ntu_logo.png
    footer: "Research Methods & Data Analysis"
    slide-number: true
    transition: slide
    background-transition: fade
    #auto-stretch: true
    title-block-banner: true

---

::: {.cell}

:::




## You should know today:

- Know when to use frequency tests
- Work with tables and graphs
- Goodness of fit tests
- Independency tests
- Homogeneity tests


## Types of variables (review)

::::{.columns}
:::{.column .fragment}
**Categorical**

![](https://static-assets.codecademy.com/Courses/Hypothesis-Testing/Intro_to_variable_types_3.png)

:::

:::{.column .fragment}
**Numerical**

![](https://static-assets.codecademy.com/Courses/Hypothesis-Testing/Intro_to_variable_types_4.png)

:::
::::

## Back to the toolbox

![](img/toolkit.png){fig-align="center"}


## Let's imagine Ladybirds

:::{.panel-tabset}

## Ladybirds

![](img/ladybirds.png){width="40%" fig-align="center"}

## Code



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ladybirds <- tribble(
  ~Habitat, ~Site, ~Colour, ~Number,
  "Rural", "R1", "Black", 10,
  "Rural", "R2", "Black", 3,
  "Rural", "R3", "Black", 4,
  "Rural", "R4", "Black", 7,
  "Rural", "R5", "Black", 6,
  "Rural", "R1", "Red", 15,
  "Rural", "R2", "Red", 18,
  "Rural", "R3", "Red", 9,
  "Rural", "R4", "Red", 12,
  "Rural", "R5", "Red", 16,
  "Industrial", "U1", "Black", 32,
  "Industrial", "U2", "Black", 25,
  "Industrial", "U3", "Black", 25,
  "Industrial", "U4", "Black", 17,
  "Industrial", "U5", "Black", 16,
  "Industrial", "U1", "Red", 17,
  "Industrial", "U2", "Red", 23,
  "Industrial", "U3", "Red", 21,
  "Industrial", "U4", "Red", 9,
  "Industrial", "U5",  
 "Red", 15
)
```
:::



## Data



::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 20 Ã— 4
   Habitat    Site  Colour Number
   <chr>      <chr> <chr>   <dbl>
 1 Rural      R1    Black      10
 2 Rural      R2    Black       3
 3 Rural      R3    Black       4
 4 Rural      R4    Black       7
 5 Rural      R5    Black       6
 6 Rural      R1    Red        15
 7 Rural      R2    Red        18
 8 Rural      R3    Red         9
 9 Rural      R4    Red        12
10 Rural      R5    Red        16
11 Industrial U1    Black      32
12 Industrial U2    Black      25
13 Industrial U3    Black      25
14 Industrial U4    Black      17
15 Industrial U5    Black      16
16 Industrial U1    Red        17
17 Industrial U2    Red        23
18 Industrial U3    Red        21
19 Industrial U4    Red         9
20 Industrial U5    Red        15
```


:::
:::



## Table 1



::: {.cell output-location='column'}

```{.r .cell-code}
ladybirds%>% 
  group_by(Habitat, Colour) %>% 
  summarize(count = sum(Number)) |> 
  kable()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}


|Habitat    |Colour | count|
|:----------|:------|-----:|
|Industrial |Black  |   115|
|Industrial |Red    |    85|
|Rural      |Black  |    30|
|Rural      |Red    |    70|


:::
:::



## Table 2



::: {.cell output-location='column'}

```{.r .cell-code}
ladybirds%>% 
  group_by(Habitat, Colour) %>% 
  summarize(count = sum(Number)) %>% 
  spread(Colour, count, fill = 0) |> 
  kable()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}


|Habitat    | Black| Red|
|:----------|-----:|---:|
|Industrial |   115|  85|
|Rural      |    30|  70|


:::
:::


:::

## How habitat type influences morphotype occurrence of ladybirds?{.center}

## Is there an association between habitat and LB morphotype?{.center}


## Tweaking tables

:::{.panel-tabset}

## Code


::: {.cell output-location='column'}

```{.r .cell-code}
ladybirds |> 
  group_by(Habitat, Colour) |> 
  summarize(count = sum(Number)) |> 
  mutate(prop=count/sum(count)) |>   # our new proportion variable
  kable()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}


|Habitat    |Colour | count|  prop|
|:----------|:------|-----:|-----:|
|Industrial |Black  |   115| 0.575|
|Industrial |Red    |    85| 0.425|
|Rural      |Black  |    30| 0.300|
|Rural      |Red    |    70| 0.700|


:::
:::



## Code 2



::: {.cell output-location='column'}

```{.r .cell-code}
ladybirds |> 
  group_by(Habitat, Colour) |> 
  summarize(count = sum(Number)) |> 
  mutate(prop=count/sum(count)) |>   # our new proportion variable
  dplyr::select(Habitat, Colour, prop) %>% 
  spread(Habitat, prop) |> 
  kable()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}


|Colour | Industrial| Rural|
|:------|----------:|-----:|
|Black  |      0.575|   0.3|
|Red    |      0.425|   0.7|


:::
:::



## Code 3



::: {.cell output-location='default'}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(janitor)
ladybirds |> 
  group_by(Habitat, Colour) %>% 
  summarize(count = sum(Number)) %>% 
  spread(Colour, count, fill = 0)|> 
  adorn_totals(c("row", "col")) |> 
  kable()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}


|Habitat    | Black| Red| Total|
|:----------|-----:|---:|-----:|
|Industrial |   115|  85|   200|
|Rural      |    30|  70|   100|
|Total      |   145| 155|   300|


:::
:::


:::

## Proportions

:::{.panel-tabset}

## Totals


::: {.cell output-location='default'}

```{.r .cell-code}
ladybirds |> 
  group_by(Habitat, Colour) %>% 
  summarize(count = sum(Number)) %>% 
  spread(Colour, count, fill = 0) |> 
  column_to_rownames("Habitat") |> 
  proportions() |> 
  kable()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}


|           |     Black|       Red|
|:----------|---------:|---------:|
|Industrial | 0.3833333| 0.2833333|
|Rural      | 0.1000000| 0.2333333|


:::
:::



## Rows


::: {.cell output-location='default'}

```{.r .cell-code}
ladybirds |> 
  group_by(Habitat, Colour) %>% 
  summarise(count = sum(Number)) %>% 
  spread(Colour, count, fill = 0) |> 
  column_to_rownames("Habitat") |> 
  as.matrix()->t
  proportions(t,1) |> 
    kable()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}


|           | Black|   Red|
|:----------|-----:|-----:|
|Industrial | 0.575| 0.425|
|Rural      | 0.300| 0.700|


:::
:::



## Columns


::: {.cell output-location='default'}

```{.r .cell-code}
ladybirds |> 
  group_by(Habitat, Colour) %>% 
  summarise(count = sum(Number)) %>% 
  spread(Colour, count, fill = 0) |> 
  column_to_rownames("Habitat") |> 
  as.matrix()->t
  proportions(t,2) |> 
    kable()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}


|           |     Black|       Red|
|:----------|---------:|---------:|
|Industrial | 0.7931034| 0.5483871|
|Rural      | 0.2068966| 0.4516129|


:::
:::


:::

## All important at once



::: {.cell output-location='default'}

```{.r .cell-code}
CrossTable(t)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

 
   Cell Contents
|-------------------------|
|                       N |
| Chi-square contribution |
|           N / Row Total |
|           N / Col Total |
|         N / Table Total |
|-------------------------|

 
Total Observations in Table:  300 

 
             |  
             |     Black |       Red | Row Total | 
-------------|-----------|-----------|-----------|
  Industrial |       115 |        85 |       200 | 
             |     3.477 |     3.253 |           | 
             |     0.575 |     0.425 |     0.667 | 
             |     0.793 |     0.548 |           | 
             |     0.383 |     0.283 |           | 
-------------|-----------|-----------|-----------|
       Rural |        30 |        70 |       100 | 
             |     6.954 |     6.505 |           | 
             |     0.300 |     0.700 |     0.333 | 
             |     0.207 |     0.452 |           | 
             |     0.100 |     0.233 |           | 
-------------|-----------|-----------|-----------|
Column Total |       145 |       155 |       300 | 
             |     0.483 |     0.517 |           | 
-------------|-----------|-----------|-----------|

 
```


:::
:::



## Proportions can be tricky

- 2/3 of LB are found in Industrial areas 
- It is rare fo find a black LB in rural areas
- Red LB don't show any habitat preference
- Black LB prefer Industrial areas

:::{.fragment}
- **How many more info can we extract from this table?**
:::

## Types do frequency tests{.center}

## Tests for independence

:::{.panel-tabset}

## Table

| Naruto fan | watched Ghibli | never watched Ghibli|
|:----------|-----:|---:|
|no |   35|  205|
|yes      |    8|  48|

## Code



::: {.cell output-location='default'}

```{.r .cell-code}
naruto<-matrix(c(35,205,8,48), nrow=2, byrow=TRUE)
chisq.test(naruto)$expected
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
          [,1]      [,2]
[1,] 34.864865 205.13514
[2,]  8.135135  47.86486
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
proportions(naruto[1,])
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 0.1458333 0.8541667
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
proportions(naruto[2,])
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 0.1428571 0.8571429
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
chisq.test(naruto)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

	Pearson's Chi-squared test with Yates' continuity correction

data:  naruto
X-squared = 5.9938e-30, df = 1, p-value = 1
```


:::
:::




:::

## Placebo effect

:::{.panel-tabset}
## Table

| Cure | treatment| placebo| no treatment|
|:----------|-----:|---:|---:|
|Yes |   43|  31| 27|
|No      |    12|  24| 28|

:::{.fragment}
- Most people is cured anyway
- Treatment improves positive resolution

:::
## Code


::: {.cell output-location='default'}

```{.r .cell-code}
placebo<-matrix(c(43,31,27,12,24,28), nrow=2, byrow=TRUE)
rownames(placebo)<-c("cure-yes", "cure-no")
colnames(placebo)<-c("treatment","placebo","no treatment")
exp.placebo<-chisq.test(placebo)$expected
exp.placebo
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
         treatment  placebo no treatment
cure-yes  33.66667 33.66667     33.66667
cure-no   21.33333 21.33333     21.33333
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
chisq.test(placebo)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

	Pearson's Chi-squared test

data:  placebo
X-squared = 10.619, df = 2, p-value = 0.004945
```


:::
:::



:::

## Chi-square test

$$Chi-squared  = \sum(Obs-Exp)Â²/Exp$$



::: {.cell output-location='default'}

```{.r .cell-code}
chisq.test(placebo)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

	Pearson's Chi-squared test

data:  placebo
X-squared = 10.619, df = 2, p-value = 0.004945
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
sum((placebo-exp.placebo)^2/exp.placebo)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 10.61881
```


:::
:::



## Testing rows
:::{.panel-tabset}

## Black LB


::: {.cell output-location='default'}

```{.r .cell-code}
t[,1] # first line, Blacks
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Industrial      Rural 
       115         30 
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
chisq.test(t[,1])$expected
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Industrial      Rural 
      72.5       72.5 
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
chisq.test(t[,1])
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

	Chi-squared test for given probabilities

data:  t[, 1]
X-squared = 49.828, df = 1, p-value = 1.679e-12
```


:::
:::



## Red LB



::: {.cell output-location='default'}

```{.r .cell-code}
t[,2] # second line, Reds
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Industrial      Rural 
        85         70 
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
chisq.test(t[,2])$expected
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Industrial      Rural 
      77.5       77.5 
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
chisq.test(t[,2])
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

	Chi-squared test for given probabilities

data:  t[, 2]
X-squared = 1.4516, df = 1, p-value = 0.2283
```


:::
:::



:::


## Testing columns

:::{.panel-tabset}

## Industrial


::: {.cell output-location='default'}

```{.r .cell-code}
t[1,]
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Black   Red 
  115    85 
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
chisq.test(t[1,])$expected
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Black   Red 
  100   100 
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
chisq.test(t[1,])
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

	Chi-squared test for given probabilities

data:  t[1, ]
X-squared = 4.5, df = 1, p-value = 0.03389
```

:::



## Rural



::: {.cell output-location='default'}

```{.r .cell-code}
t[2,]
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Black   Red 
   30    70 
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
chisq.test(t[2,])$expected
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Black   Red 
   50    50 
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
chisq.test(t[2,])
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

	Chi-squared test for given probabilities

data:  t[2, ]
X-squared = 16, df = 1, p-value = 6.334e-05
```


:::
:::


:::

## Test for homogeneity
:::{.panel-tabset}
## Data



::: {.cell output-location='column'}

```{.r .cell-code}
pop<-tribble(
  ~age, ~country, ~pop,
       "0-10","UK", 50,
       "0-10","BRA", 120,
       "11-20","UK", 70,
       "11-20","BRA", 140,
       "21-30","UK", 110,
       "21-30","BRA", 150,
       "31-40","UK", 150,
       "31-40","BRA", 180,
       "40-50","UK", 180,
       "40-50","BRA", 180,
       "50-60","UK", 150,
       "50-60","BRA", 90,
       "60-70","UK", 130,
       "60-70","BRA", 50)
```
:::



## Graph


::: {.cell output-location='column'}

```{.r .cell-code}
pop |> 
  ggplot(aes(x=age, y= pop, color=country, fill=country))+
  geom_col(position="dodge")+
  theme(axis.text=element_text(size = 18),
        axis.title = element_text(size=18))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](06_freq_tests_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-21-1.png){width=960}
:::
:::



## Chi square test



::: {.cell output-location='column'}

```{.r .cell-code}
pop |> 
  group_by(country, age) %>% 
  #summarise(count = sum(Number)) %>% 
  spread(country, pop, fill = 0) |> 
  column_to_rownames("age") |> 
  as.matrix() -> t2
  chisq.test(t2)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

	Pearson's Chi-squared test

data:  t2
X-squared = 108.97, df = 6, p-value < 2.2e-16
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
  chisq.test(t2)$observed-chisq.test(t2)$expected
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
        BRA    UK
0-10   31.6 -31.6
11-20  30.8 -30.8
21-30  14.8 -14.8
31-40   8.4  -8.4
40-50  -7.2   7.2
50-60 -34.8  34.8
60-70 -43.6  43.6
```


:::
:::



:::

## Goodness of fit

:::{.panel-tabset}

## Data



::: {.cell output-location='column'}

```{.r .cell-code}
pop %>% 
  spread(country, pop, fill=0) %>% 
  mutate(world=(BRA+UK)/2) %>% 
  pivot_longer(cols = BRA:world, names_to = "place")->pop2
pop2  
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 21 Ã— 3
   age   place value
   <chr> <chr> <dbl>
 1 0-10  BRA     120
 2 0-10  UK       50
 3 0-10  world    85
 4 11-20 BRA     140
 5 11-20 UK       70
 6 11-20 world   105
 7 21-30 BRA     150
 8 21-30 UK      110
 9 21-30 world   130
10 31-40 BRA     180
# â„¹ 11 more rows
```


:::
:::



## Graph


::: {.cell output-location='column'}

```{.r .cell-code}
pop2 %>%
  ggplot(aes(x=age,y=value, colour=place, fill=place))+
  geom_col(position = "dodge")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](06_freq_tests_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-24-1.png){width=960}
:::
:::


## Test


::: {.cell output-location='column'}

```{.r .cell-code}
pop2 %>% 
  spread(place, value, fill = 0) %>% 
  column_to_rownames("age")-> pop3
  chisq.test(pop3$BR, pop3$world)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

	Pearson's Chi-squared test

data:  pop3$BR and pop3$world
X-squared = 35, df = 30, p-value = 0.2426
```


:::
:::





:::

## Loglinear models

- Based on contingency tables with multiple levels
- Can model data
- Based on odds ratio

:::{.fragment}

### BEAUTIFUL
:::

## Multiple contingency tables



::: {.cell output-location='default'}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(MASS)
pop |> 
  rename(male=pop) |> 
  mutate(female=ifelse(country=="UK", male^1.01, male^1.03)) |> 
  pivot_longer(cols = male:female, names_to = "sex")->dat.mod

model1<-glm(value~age*country*sex, data=dat.mod, family="poisson")

summary(model1)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

Call:

    data = dat.mod)
```

:::
:::



## Frequency tests

- Chi-square test
- Z-test
- G test
- Binomial tests
- Loglinear models*

## Key points
- Can you identify when you need a frequency test?
- Are you able to extract the info from the tables and graphics?
- Can you interpret correctly the results?


## End of DA class{.center}

include-after-body:
<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
